name: Date

types.name: Date
types.comment: Representation of a date.

types.name: Day
types.comment: Represents the days of the week.

types.name: Month
types.comment: Represents the month of the year.

values.name: day
values.comment:
Extract the day of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `23`.

values.name: dayOfWeek
values.comment:
Extract the day of the week for a given date. Given the date 23 June
1990 at 11:45AM this returns the Day `Thu` as defined below.

values.name: fromString
values.comment: Attempt to read a date from a string.

values.name: fromTime
values.comment: Take a UNIX time and convert it to a `Date`.

values.name: hour
values.comment:
Extract the hour of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `11`.

values.name: millisecond
values.comment:
Extract the millisecond of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45:30.123AM
this returns the integer `123`.

values.name: minute
values.comment:
Extract the minute of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `45`.

values.name: month
values.comment:
Extract the month of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the Month `Jun` as defined below.

values.name: second
values.comment:
Extract the second of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `0`.

values.name: toTime
values.comment:
Convert a date into a time since midnight (UTC) of 1 January 1970 (i.e.
[UNIX time](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time)). Given the date 23 June
1990 at 11:45AM this returns the corresponding time.

values.name: year
values.comment:
Extract the year of a given date. Given the date 23 June 1990 at 11:45AM
this returns the integer `1990`.

name: Touch

aliases.name: Touch
aliases.comment:
Every `Touch` has `xy` coordinates. It also has an identifier
`id` to distinguish one touch from another.

A touch also keeps info about the initial point and time of contact:
`x0`, `y0`, and `t0`. This helps compute more complicated gestures
like taps, drags, and swipes which need to know about timing or direction.
aliases.type: { x : Int, y : Int, id : Int, x0 : Int, y0 : Int, t0 : Time.Time }

values.name: taps
values.comment:
The last position that was tapped. Default value is `{x=0,y=0}`.
Updates whenever the user taps the screen.

values.name: touches
values.comment: A list of ongoing touches.

name: Graphics.Input
comment:
This module is for creating input widgets such as buttons and text fields.
All functions in this library report to a [`Signal.Mailbox`](Signal#message).

# Basic Input Elements

To learn about text fields, see the
[`Graphics.Input.Field`](Graphics-Input-Field) library.

@docs button, customButton, checkbox, dropDown

# Clicks and Hovers
@docs clickable, hoverable

values.name: button
values.comment:
Create a standard button. The following example begins making a basic
calculator:

    type Keys = Number Int | Plus | Minus | Clear

    keys : Signal.Mailbox Keys
    keys = Signal.mailbox Clear

    calculator : Element
    calculator =
        flow right
          [ button (Signal.message keys.address (Number 1)) "1"
          , button (Signal.message keys.address (Number 2)) "2"
          , button (Signal.message keys.address    Plus   ) "+"
          ]

If the user presses the "+" button, `keys.signal` will update to `Plus`. If the
users presses "2", `keys.signal` will update to `(Number 2)`.

values.name: checkbox
values.comment:
Create a checkbox. The following example creates three synced checkboxes:

    check : Signal.Mailbox Bool
    check = Signal.mailbox False

    boxes : Bool -> Element
    boxes checked =
        let box = container 40 40 middle (checkbox (Signal.message check.address) checked)
        in
            flow right [ box, box, box ]

    main : Signal Element
    main = Signal.map boxes check.signal

values.name: clickable
values.comment:
Detect mouse clicks on a specific `Element`. In the following example,
we will create a clickable picture called `cat`.

    type Picture = Cat | Hat

    picture : Signal.Mailbox Picture
    picture = Signal.mailbox Cat

    cat : Element
    cat =
      image 30 30 "/cat.jpg"
        |> clickable (Signal.message picture.address Cat)

    hat : Element
    hat =
      image 30 30 "/hat.jpg"
        |> clickable (Signal.message picture.address Hat)

When the user clicks on the `cat` element, `picture.signal` receives
an update containing the value `Cat`. When the user clicks on the `hat` element,
`picture.signal` receives an update containing the value `Hat`. This lets you
distinguish which element was clicked. In a more complex example, they could be
distinguished with IDs or more complex data structures.

values.name: customButton
values.comment:
Same as `button` but lets you customize buttons to look however you want.

    click : Signal.Mailbox ()
    click = Signal.mailbox ()

    prettyButton : Element
    prettyButton =
        customButton (Signal.message click.address ())
            (image 100 40 "/button_up.jpg")
            (image 100 40 "/button_hover.jpg")
            (image 100 40 "/button_down.jpg")

values.name: dropDown
values.comment:
Create a drop-down menu.  The following drop-down lets you choose your
favorite British sport:

    type Sport = Football | Cricket | Snooker

    sport : Signal.Mailbox (Maybe Sport)
    sport = Signal.mailbox Nothing

    sportDropDown : Element
    sportDropDown =
        dropDown (Signal.message sport.address)
          [ (""        , Nothing)
          , ("Football", Just Football)
          , ("Cricket" , Just Cricket)
          , ("Snooker" , Just Snooker)
          ]

If the user selects "Football" from the drop down menu, `sport.signal`
will update to `Just Football`.

values.name: hoverable
values.comment:
Detect mouse hovers over a specific `Element`. In the following example,
we will create a hoverable picture called `cat`.

    hover : Signal.Mailbox Bool
    hover = Signal.mailbox False

    cat : Element
    cat =
      image 30 30 "/cat.jpg"
        |> hoverable (Signal.message hover.address)

When the mouse hovers above the `cat` element, `hover.signal` will become
`True`. When the mouse leaves it, `hover.signal` will become `False`.

name: Graphics.Input.Field

aliases.name: Content
aliases.comment:
Represents the current content of a text field. For example:

    content = Content "She sells sea shells" (Selection 0 3 Backward)

This means the user highlighted the substring `"She"` backwards. The value of
`content.string` is `"She sells sea shells"`.

aliases.name: Dimensions
aliases.comment:
For setting dimensions of a field's padding or outline. The left, right,
top, and bottom may all have different sizes. The following example creates
dimensions such that the left and right are twice as wide as the top and bottom:

    myDimensions : Int -> Dimensions
    myDimensions n =
        { left = 2 * n
        , right = 2 * n
        , top = n
        , bottom = n
        }
aliases.type: { left : Int, right : Int, top : Int, bottom : Int }

aliases.name: Highlight
aliases.comment:
When a field has focus, it has a blue highlight around it by default. The
`Highlight` lets you set the `color` and `width` of this highlight. Set the
`width` to zero to turn the highlight off. Here is an example highlight that
is blue and thin:

    { color = blue, width = 1 }

aliases.name: Outline
aliases.comment:
A field can have a outline around it. This lets you set its color, width,
and radius. The radius allows you to round the corners of your field. Set the
width to zero to make it invisible. Here is an example outline that is grey
and thin with slightly rounded corners:

    { color = grey, width = uniformly 1, radius = 4 }
aliases.type: { color : Color.Color , width : Graphics.Input.Field.Dimensions , radius : Int }

aliases.name: Selection
aliases.comment:
The selection within a text field. `start` is never greater than `end`:

    Selection 0 0 Forward  -- cursor precedes all characters

    Selection 5 9 Backward -- highlighting characters starting after
                           -- the 5th and ending after the 9th
aliases.type: { start : Int , end : Int , direction : Graphics.Input.Field.Direction }

aliases.name: Style
aliases.comment:
Describe the style of a text box. `style` describes the style of the text
itself using [`Text.Style`](Text#Style). `highlight` describes the glowing blue
highlight that shows up when the field has focus. `outline` describes the line
surrounding the text field, and `padding` adds whitespace between the `outline`
and the text.

The width and height of the text box *includes* the `padding` and `outline`.
Say we have a text box that is 40 pixels tall. It has a uniform outline of
1 pixel and a uniform padding of 5 pixels. Both of these must be subtracted
from the total height to determine how much room there is for text. The
`padding` and `outline` appear on the top and bottom, so there will be 28
vertical pixels remaining for the text (40 - 1 - 5 - 5 - 1).
aliases.type: { padding : Graphics.Input.Field.Dimensions , outline : Graphics.Input.Field.Outline , highlight : Graphics.Input.Field.Highlight , style : Text.Style }

types.name: Direction
types.comment:
The direction of selection. When the user highlights a selection in a text
field, they must do it in a particular direction. This determines which end of
the selection moves when they change the selection by pressing Shift-Left or
Shift-Right.

values.name: defaultStyle
values.comment:
The default style for a text field. The outline is `Color.grey` with width
1 and radius 2. The highlight is `Color.blue` with width 1, and the default
text color is black.

values.name: email
values.comment:
Same as `field` but it adds an annotation that this field is for email
addresses. This is helpful for auto-complete and for mobile users who may
get a custom keyboard with an `@` and `.com` button.

values.name: field
values.comment:
Create a text field. The following example creates a time-varying element
called `nameField`. As the user types their name, the field will be updated
to match what they have entered.

    name : Signal.Mailbox Content
    name = Signal.mailbox noContent

    nameField : Signal Element
    nameField =
        Signal.map (field defaultStyle (Signal.message name.address) "Name") name.signal

When we use the `field` function, we first give it a visual style. This is
the first argument so that it is easier to define your own custom field
(`myField = field myStyle`). The next two arguments are a `Handle` and a
handler function that processes or augments events before sending them along
to the associated `Input`. In the example above we use the `identity` function to
pass events along unchanged to the `name` `Input`. We then provide the
place-holder message to use when no input has been provided yet. Finally,
we give the current `Content` of the field. This argument is last because
it is most likely to change frequently, making function composition easier.

values.name: noContent
values.comment:
A field with no content:

    Content "" (Selection 0 0 Forward)

values.name: noHighlight
values.comment: A highlight with zero width, so you cannot see it.

values.name: noOutline
values.comment: An outline with zero width, so you cannot see it.

values.name: password
values.comment: Same as `field` but the UI element blocks out each characters.

values.name: uniformly
values.comment:
Create uniform dimensions:

    uniformly 4 == { left=4, right=4, top=4, bottom=4 }

The following example creates an outline where the left, right, top, and bottom
edges all have width 1:

    Outline grey (uniformly 1) 4

name: Window
comment:
Provides information about the container that your Elm program lives in.
When you embed Elm in a `<div>` it gives the dimensions of the container, not
the whole window.

# Dimensions
@docs dimensions, width, height

values.name: dimensions
values.comment:
The current width and height of the window (i.e. the area viewable to the
user, not including scroll bars).

values.name: height
values.comment: The current height of the window.

values.name: width
values.comment: The current width of the window.

name: Time

aliases.name: Time
aliases.comment:
Type alias to make it clearer when you are working with time values.
Using the `Time` constants instead of raw numbers is very highly recommended.

values.name: delay
values.comment:
Delay a signal by a certain amount of time. So `(delay second Mouse.clicks)`
will update one second later than any mouse click.

Note: Even calling `delay` with the same number on the same signal twice
gives two independently firing signals.

values.name: every
values.comment:
Takes a time interval `t`. The resulting signal is the current time, updated
every `t`.

Note: Calling `every 100` twice gives two independently running timers.

values.name: fps
values.comment:
Takes desired number of frames per second (FPS). The resulting signal
gives a sequence of time deltas as quickly as possible until it reaches
the desired FPS. A time delta is the time between the last frame and the
current frame.

Note: Calling `fps 30` twice gives two independently running timers.

values.name: fpsWhen
values.comment:
Same as the `fps` function, but you can turn it on and off. Allows you
to do brief animations based on user input without major inefficiencies.
The first time delta after a pause is always zero, no matter how long
the pause was. This way summing the deltas will actually give the amount
of time that the output signal has been running.

values.name: millisecond
values.comment:
Units of time, making it easier to specify things like a half-second
`(500 * millisecond)` without remembering Elm’s underlying units of time.

values.name: since
values.comment:
Takes a time `t` and any signal. The resulting boolean signal is true for
time `t` after every event on the input signal. So ``(second `since`
Mouse.clicks)`` would result in a signal that is true for one second after
each mouse click and false otherwise.

values.name: timestamp
values.comment:
Add a timestamp to any signal. Timestamps increase monotonically. When you
create `(timestamp Mouse.x)`, an initial timestamp is produced. The timestamp
updates whenever `Mouse.x` updates.

Timestamp updates are tied to individual events, so `(timestamp Mouse.x)` and
`(timestamp Mouse.y)` will always have the same timestamp because they rely on
the same underlying event (`Mouse.position`).

name: Keyboard

values.name: arrows
values.comment:
A signal of records indicating which arrow keys are pressed.

  * `{ x = 0, y = 0 }` when pressing no arrows.
  * `{ x =-1, y = 0 }` when pressing the left arrow.
  * `{ x = 1, y = 1 }` when pressing the up and right arrows.
  * `{ x = 0, y =-1 }` when pressing the down, left, and right arrows.

values.name: isDown
values.comment: Whether an arbitrary key is pressed.

values.name: keysDown
values.comment: Set of keys that are currently down.

values.name: meta
values.comment: The meta key is the Windows key on Windows and the Command key on Mac.

values.name: presses
values.comment: The latest key that has been pressed.

values.name: wasd
values.comment:
Just like the arrows signal, but this uses keys w, a, s, and d,
which are common controls for many computer games.

name: Mouse

values.name: clicks
values.comment: Always equal to unit. Event triggers on every mouse click.

values.name: isDown
values.comment:
The current state of the mouse
True when any mouse button is down, and false otherwise.

values.name: position
values.comment: The current mouse position.

values.name: x
values.comment: The current x-coordinate of the mouse.

values.name: y
values.comment: The current y-coordinate of the mouse.

name: Signal

aliases.name: Mailbox
aliases.comment:
A `Mailbox` is a communication hub. It is made up of

  * an `Address` that you can send messages to
  * a `Signal` of messages sent to the mailbox
aliases.type: { address : Signal.Address a, signal : Signal.Signal a }

types.name: Address
types.comment:
An `Address` points to a specific signal. It allows you to feed values into
signals, so you can provide your own signal updates.

The primary use case is when a `Task` or UI element needs to talk back to the
main part of your application.

types.name: Message
types.comment:
A `Message` is like an envelope that you have not yet put in a mailbox.
The address is filled out and the envelope is filled, but it will be sent at
some point in the future.

types.name: Signal
types.comment:
A value that changes over time. So a `(Signal Int))` is an integer that is
varying as time passes, perhaps representing the current window width of the
browser. Every signal is updated at discrete moments in response to events in
the world.

values.name: constant
values.comment:
Create a signal that never changes. This can be useful if you need
to pass a combination of signals and normal values to a function:

    map3 view Window.dimensions Mouse.position (constant initialModel)

values.name: dropRepeats
values.comment:
Drop updates that repeat the current value of the signal.

    numbers : Signal Int

    noDups : Signal Int
    noDups =
        dropRepeats numbers

    --  numbers => 0 0 3 3 5 5 5 4 ...
    --  noDups  => 0   3   5     4 ...

The signal should not be a signal of functions, or a record that contains a
function (you'll get a runtime error since functions cannot be equated).

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Filter out some updates. The given function decides whether we should
*keep* an update. If no updates ever flow through, we use the default value
provided. The following example only keeps even numbers and has an initial
value of zero.

    numbers : Signal Int

    isEven : Int -> Bool

    evens : Signal Int
    evens =
        filter isEven 0 numbers
values.type: (a -> Bool) -> a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: filterMap
values.comment:
Filter out some updates. When the filter function gives back `Just` a
value, we send that value along. When it returns `Nothing` we drop it.
If the initial value of the incoming signal turns into `Nothing`, we use the
default value provided. The following example keeps only strings that can be
read as integers.

    userInput : Signal String

    toInt : String -> Maybe Int

    numbers : Signal Int
    numbers =
        filterMap toInt 0 userInput
values.type: (a -> Maybe.Maybe b) -> b -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: foldp
values.comment:
Create a past-dependent signal. Each update from the incoming signals will
be used to step the state forward. The outgoing signal represents the current
state.

    clickCount : Signal Int
    clickCount =
        foldp (\click total -> total + 1) 0 Mouse.clicks

    timeSoFar : Signal Time
    timeSoFar =
        foldp (+) 0 (fps 40)

So `clickCount` updates on each mouse click, incrementing by one. `timeSoFar`
is the time the program has been running, updated 40 times a second.
values.type: (a -> state -> state) -> state -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal state

values.name: forwardTo
values.comment:
Create a new address. This address will tag each message it receives
and then forward it along to some other address.

    type Action = Undo | Remove Int | NoOp

    actions : Mailbox Action
    actions = mailbox NoOp

    removeAddress : Address Int
    removeAddress =
        forwardTo actions.address Remove

In this case we have a general `address` that many people may send
messages to. The new `removeAddress` tags all messages with the `Remove` tag
before forwarding them along to the more general `address`. This means
some parts of our application can know *only* about `removeAddress` and not
care what other kinds of `Actions` are possible.

values.name: mailbox
values.comment:
Create a mailbox you can send messages to. The primary use case is
receiving updates from tasks and UI elements. The argument is a default value
for the custom signal.

Note: Creating new signals is inherently impure, so `(mailbox ())` and
`(mailbox ())` produce two different mailboxes.

values.name: map
values.comment:
Apply a function to a signal.

    mouseIsUp : Signal Bool
    mouseIsUp =
        map not Mouse.isDown

    main : Signal Element
    main =
        map Graphics.Element.show Mouse.position

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Apply a function to the current value of two signals. The function
is reevaluated whenever *either* signal changes. In the following example, we
figure out the `aspectRatio` of the window by combining the current width and
height.

    ratio : Int -> Int -> Float
    ratio width height =
        toFloat width / toFloat height

    aspectRatio : Signal Float
    aspectRatio =
        map2 ratio Window.width Window.height
values.type: (a -> b -> result) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal result

values.name: map3
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> result) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal c -> Signal.Signal result

values.name: map4
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> result) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal c -> Signal.Signal d -> Signal.Signal result

values.name: map5
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> result) -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal c -> Signal.Signal d -> Signal.Signal e -> Signal.Signal result

values.name: merge
values.comment:
Merge two signals into one. This function is extremely useful for bringing
together lots of different signals to feed into a `foldp`.

    type Update = MouseMove (Int,Int) | TimeDelta Float

    updates : Signal Update
    updates =
        merge
            (map MouseMove Mouse.position)
            (map TimeDelta (fps 40))

If an update comes from either of the incoming signals, it updates the outgoing
signal. If an update comes on both signals at the same time, the update provided
by the left input signal wins (i.e., the update from the second signal is discarded).
values.type: Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal a

values.name: mergeMany
values.comment:
Merge many signals into one. This is useful when you are merging more than
two signals. When multiple updates come in at the same time, the left-most
update wins, just like with `merge`.

    type Update = MouseMove (Int,Int) | TimeDelta Float | Click

    updates : Signal Update
    updates =
        mergeMany
            [ map MouseMove Mouse.position
            , map TimeDelta (fps 40)
            , map (always Click) Mouse.clicks
            ]

values.name: message
values.comment:
Create a message that may be sent to a `Mailbox` at a later time.

Most importantly, this lets us create APIs that can send values to ports
*without* allowing people to run arbitrary tasks.

values.name: sampleOn
values.comment:
Sample from the second input every time an event occurs on the first input.
For example, `(sampleOn Mouse.clicks (Time.every Time.second))` will give the
approximate time of the latest click.
values.type: Signal.Signal a -> Signal.Signal b -> Signal.Signal b

values.name: send
values.comment:
Send a message to an `Address`.

    type Action = Undo | Remove Int

    address : Address Action

    requestUndo : Task x ()
    requestUndo =
        send address Undo

The `Signal` associated with `address` will receive the `Undo` message
and push it through the Elm program.

name: Debug

values.name: crash
values.comment:
Crash the program with an error message. This is an uncatchable error,
intended for code that is soon-to-be-implemented. For example, if you are
working with a large ADT and have partially completed a case expression, it may
make sense to do this:

    data Entity = Ship | Fish | Captain | Seagull

    drawEntity entity =
        case entity of
          Ship ->
              ...

          Fish ->
              ...

          _ ->
              Debug.crash "TODO"

The Elm compiler recognizes each `Debug.crash` and when you run into it at
runtime, the error will point to the corresponding module name and line number.
For `case` expressions that ends with a wildcard pattern and a crash, it will
also show the value that snuck through. In our example, that'd be `Captain` or
`Seagull`.

**Use this if** you want to do some testing while you are partway through
writing a function.

**Do not use this if** you want to do some typical try-catch exception handling.
Use the [`Maybe`](Maybe) or [`Result`](Result) libraries instead.

values.name: log
values.comment:
Log a tagged value on the developer console, and then return the value.

    1 + log "number" 1        -- equals 2, logs "number: 1"
    length (log "start" [])   -- equals 0, logs "start: []"

Notice that `log` is not a pure function! It should *only* be used for
investigating bugs or performance problems.

values.name: trace
values.comment:
Trace all past positions of a `Form` in the debugger. Add this to a `Form`
and you will see a line tracing its entire history.

values.name: watch
values.comment:
Watch a particular value in the debugger. Say we want to know the value of
a variable called `velocity` because it may not be updated correctly. Adding
`Debug.watch` allows us to name the value and show it with the debugger. The
result of evaluating such an expression is unchanged.

	  Debug.watch "velocity" velocity == velocity

That means it's easy to add `Debug.watch` to any value.

Note that calling `Debug.watch` on a signal is not useful. Instead, it needs
to be mapped into the signal (to act on the contained value). So if you want
to watch a timer signal, instead of `Debug.watch "time" (Time.every 1000)`
you need `Signal.map (Debug.watch "time") (Time.every 1000)`.

values.name: watchSummary
values.comment:
Watch a summary of a particular value in the debugger. This function is
pretty much the same as `watch` but it lets you specify a way to summarize
the value you are interested in. For example, maybe you only want to see part
of a record:

	  Debug.watchSummary "velocity" .velocity object

This is the same as just writing `object`, but it creates a watch that *only*
looks at the value of `object.velocity`. You can also show summary statistics
like length of a list:

	  Debug.watchSummary "Number of clicks" length clicks

Again, this evaluates to `clicks` but we get to see how long that list is in
the debugger.

name: Set

types.name: Set
types.comment:
Represents a set of unique values. So `(Set Int)` is a set of integers and
`(Set String)` is a set of strings.

values.name: diff
values.comment:
Get the difference between the first set and the second. Keeps values
that do not appear in the second set.
values.type: Set.Set comparable -> Set.Set comparable -> Set.Set comparable

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty set.

values.name: filter
values.comment: Create a new set consisting only of elements which satisfy a predicate.

values.name: foldl
values.comment: Fold over the values in a set, in order from lowest to highest.
values.type: (comparable -> b -> b) -> b -> Set.Set comparable -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment: Fold over the values in a set, in order from highest to lowest.
values.type: (comparable -> b -> b) -> b -> Set.Set comparable -> b

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert a list into a set, removing any duplicates.

values.name: insert
values.comment: Insert a value into a set.

values.name: intersect
values.comment: Get the intersection of two sets. Keeps values that appear in both sets.
values.type: Set.Set comparable -> Set.Set comparable -> Set.Set comparable

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment: Determine if a set is empty.

values.name: map
values.comment: Map a function onto a set, creating a new set with no duplicates.

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a value is in a set.

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Create two new sets; the first consisting of elements which satisfy a
predicate, the second consisting of elements which do not.
values.type: (comparable -> Bool) -> Set.Set comparable -> ( Set.Set comparable, Set.Set comparable )

values.name: remove
values.comment: Remove a value from a set. If the value is not found, no changes are made.

values.name: singleton
values.comment: Create a set with one value.

values.name: size
values.comment: Determine the number of elements in a set.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a set into a list, sorted from lowest to highest.

values.name: union
values.comment: Get the union of two sets. Keep all values.
values.type: Set.Set comparable -> Set.Set comparable -> Set.Set comparable

name: Json.Decode

types.name: Decoder
types.comment:
Represents a way of decoding JSON values. If you have a `(Decoder (List String))`
it will attempt to take some JSON value and turn it into a list of strings.
These decoders are easy to put together so you can create more and more complex
decoders.

values.comment:
Applies the decoder to the field with the given name.
Fails if the JSON object has no such field.

    nameAndAge : Decoder (String,Int)
    nameAndAge =
        object2 (,)
          ("name" := string)
          ("age" := int)

    optionalProfession : Decoder (Maybe String)
    optionalProfession =
        maybe ("profession" := string)

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
Helpful when one field will determine the shape of a bunch of other fields.

    type Shape
        = Rectangle Float Float
        | Circle Float

    shape : Decoder Shape
    shape =
      ("tag" := string) `andThen` shapeInfo

    shapeInfo : String -> Decoder Shape
    shapeInfo tag =
      case tag of
        "rectangle" ->
            object2 Rectangle
              ("width" := float)
              ("height" := float)

        "circle" ->
            object1 Circle
              ("radius" := float)

        _ ->
            fail (tag ++ " is not a recognized tag for shapes")
values.type: Json.Decode.Decoder a -> (a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b) -> Json.Decode.Decoder b

values.name: array
values.comment:
Extract an Array from a JS array.

    -- [1,2,3,4]

    numbers : Decoder (Array Int)
    numbers =
        array int

values.name: at
values.comment:
Access a nested field, making it easy to dive into big structures. This is
really a helper function so you do not need to write `(:=)` so many times.

    -- object.target.value = 'hello'
    value : Decoder String
    value =
        at ["target", "value"] string

It is defined as

    at fields decoder =
        List.foldr (:=) decoder fields
values.type: List String -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder a

values.name: bool
values.comment:
Extract a boolean.

    -- { ... checked: true ... }

    checked : Decoder Bool
    checked =
        "checked" := bool

values.name: customDecoder
values.comment:
Create a custom decoder that may do some fancy computation. See the `value`
documentation for an example usage.
values.type: Json.Decode.Decoder a -> (a -> Result.Result String b) -> Json.Decode.Decoder b

values.name: decodeString
values.comment:
Using a certain decoder, attempt to parse a JSON string. If the decoder
fails, you will get a string message telling you why.

    decodeString (tuple2 float float) "[3,4]"                  -- Ok (3,4)
    decodeString (tuple2 float float) "{ \"x\": 3, \"y\": 4 }" -- Err ""
values.type: Json.Decode.Decoder a -> String -> Result.Result String a

values.name: decodeValue
values.comment:
Using a certain decoder, attempt to parse a raw `Json.Value`. You can pass
a `Json.Value` into Elm through a port, so this can let you handle data with
extra weird shapes or stuff that currently is not allowed through ports
automatically.

    port jsonValues : Signal Json.Value

    shapes : Signal (Result String Shape)
    shapes =
      Signal.map (decodeValue shape) jsonValues

    type Shape
        = Rectangle Float Float
        | Circle Float

    shape : Decoder Shape  -- see definition in `andThen` docs
values.type: Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Value -> Result.Result String a

values.name: dict
values.comment:
Turn any object into a dictionary of key-value pairs.

    -- { mercury: 0.33, venus: 4.87, earth: 5.97, ... }
    planetMasses : Decoder (Dict String Float)
    planetMasses =
        dict float

values.name: fail
values.comment:
A decoder that always fails. Useful when paired with `andThen` or `oneOf`
to improve error messages when things go wrong. For example, the following
decoder is able to provide a much more specific error message when `fail` is
the last option.

    point : Decoder (Float,Float)
    point =
        oneOf
        [ tuple2 (,) float float
        , object2 (,) ("x" := float) ("y" := float)
        , fail "expecting some kind of point"
        ]

values.name: float
values.comment:
Extract a float.

    -- [ 6.022, 3.1415, 1.618 ]

    numbers : Decoder (List Float)
    numbers =
        list float

values.name: int
values.comment:
Extract an integer.

    -- { ... age: 42 ... }

    age : Decoder Int
    age =
        "age" := int

values.name: keyValuePairs
values.comment:
Turn any object into a list of key-value pairs. Fails if _any_ key can't be
decoded with the given decoder.

    -- { tom: 89, sue: 92, bill: 97, ... }
    grades : Decoder (List (String, Int))
    grades =
        keyValuePairs int

values.name: list
values.comment:
Extract a List from a JS array.

    -- [1,2,3,4]

    numbers : Decoder (List Int)
    numbers =
        list int

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the value returned by a decoder. Most useful when paired with
the `oneOf` function.

    nullOr : Decoder a -> Decoder (Maybe a)
    nullOr decoder =
        oneOf
          [ null Nothing
          , map Just decoder
          ]

    type UserID = OldID Int | NewID String

    -- 1234 or "1234abc"
    userID : Decoder UserID
    userID =
        oneOf
          [ map OldID int
          , map NewID string
          ]

values.name: maybe
values.comment:
Extract a Maybe value, wrapping successes with `Just` and turning any
failure in `Nothing`. If you are expecting that a field can sometimes be `null`,
it's better to check for it [explicitly](#null), as this function will swallow
errors from ill-formed JSON.

The following code decodes JSON objects that may not have a profession field.

    -- profession: Just "plumber"
    -- { name: "Tom", age: 31, profession: "plumber" }
    -- profession: Nothing
    -- { name: "Sue", age: 42 }
    -- { name: "Amy", age: 27, profession: null }
    -- { name: "Joe", age: 36, profession: ["something", "unexpected"] }

    type alias Person =
        { name : String
        , age : Int
        , profession : Maybe String
        }

    person : Decoder Person
    person =
        object3 Person
          ("name" := string)
          ("age" := int)
          (maybe ("profession" := string))

values.name: null
values.comment:
Decode null as the value given, and fail otherwise. Primarily useful for
creating *other* decoders.

    numbers : Decoder [Int]
    numbers =
        list (oneOf [ int, null 0 ])

This decoder treats `null` as `Nothing`, and otherwise tries to produce a
`Just`.

    nullOr : Decoder a -> Decoder (Maybe a)
    nullOr decoder =
        oneOf
        [ null Nothing
        , map Just decoder
        ]

values.name: object1
values.comment:
Apply a function to a decoder. You can use this function as `map` if you
must (which can be done with any `objectN` function actually).

    object1 sqrt ("x" := float)

values.name: object2
values.comment:
Use two different decoders on a JS value. This is nice for extracting
multiple fields from an object.

    point : Decoder (Float,Float)
    point =
        object2 (,)
          ("x" := float)
          ("y" := float)
values.type: (a -> b -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: object3
values.comment:
Use three different decoders on a JS value. This is nice for extracting
multiple fields from an object.

    type alias Job = { name : String, id : Int, completed : Bool }

    point : Decoder Job
    point =
        object3 Job
          ("name" := string)
          ("id" := int)
          ("completed" := bool)
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: object4
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: object5
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder e -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: object6
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder e -> Json.Decode.Decoder f -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: object7
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder e -> Json.Decode.Decoder f -> Json.Decode.Decoder g -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: object8
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> h -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder e -> Json.Decode.Decoder f -> Json.Decode.Decoder g -> Json.Decode.Decoder h -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: oneOf
values.comment:
Try out multiple different decoders. This is helpful when you are dealing
with something with a very strange shape and when `andThen` does not help
narrow things down so you can be more targeted.

    -- [ [3,4], { x:0, y:0 }, [5,12] ]

    points : Decoder (List (Float,Float))
    points =
        list point

    point : Decoder (Float,Float)
    point =
        oneOf
        [ tuple2 (,) float float
        , object2 (,) ("x" := float) ("y" := float)
        ]

values.name: string
values.comment:
Extract a string.

    -- ["John","Doe"]

    name : Decoder (String, String)
    name =
        tuple2 (,) string string

values.name: succeed
values.comment:
A decoder that always succeeds. Useful when paired with `andThen` or
`oneOf` but everything is supposed to work out at the end. For example,
maybe you have an optional field that can have a default value when it is
missing.

    -- { x:3, y:4 } or { x:3, y:4, z:5 }

    point3D : Decoder (Float,Float,Float)
    point3D =
        object3 (,,)
          ("x" := float)
          ("y" := float)
          (oneOf [ "z" := float, succeed 0 ])

values.name: tuple1
values.comment:
Handle an array with exactly one element.

    extractString : Decoder String
    extractString = 
        tuple1 identity string

    authorship : Decoder String
    authorship =
        oneOf
          [ tuple1 (\author -> "Author: " ++ author) string
          , list string |> map (\authors -> "Co-authors: " ++ String.join ", " authors)
          ]

values.name: tuple2
values.comment:
Handle an array with exactly two elements. Useful for points and simple
pairs.

    -- [3,4] or [0,0]
    point : Decoder (Float,Float)
    point =
        tuple2 (,) float float

    -- ["John","Doe"] or ["Hermann","Hesse"]
    name : Decoder Name
    name =
        tuple2 Name string string

    type alias Name = { first : String, last : String }
values.type: (a -> b -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: tuple3
values.comment:
Handle an array with exactly three elements.

    -- [3,4,5] or [0,0,0]
    point3D : Decoder (Float,Float,Float)
    point3D =
        tuple3 (,,) float float float
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: tuple4
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: tuple5
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder e -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: tuple6
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder e -> Json.Decode.Decoder f -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: tuple7
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder e -> Json.Decode.Decoder f -> Json.Decode.Decoder g -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: tuple8
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> h -> value) -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> Json.Decode.Decoder b -> Json.Decode.Decoder c -> Json.Decode.Decoder d -> Json.Decode.Decoder e -> Json.Decode.Decoder f -> Json.Decode.Decoder g -> Json.Decode.Decoder h -> Json.Decode.Decoder value

values.name: value
values.comment:
Bring in an arbitrary JSON value. Useful if you need to work with crazily
formatted data. For example, this lets you create a parser for "variadic" lists
where the first few types are different, followed by 0 or more of the same
type.

    variadic2 : (a -> b -> List c -> value) -> Decoder a -> Decoder b -> Decoder c -> Decoder value
    variadic2 f a b c =
        let
            combineResults = List.foldr (Result.map2 (::)) (Ok [])
        in
            customDecoder (list value) (\jsonList ->
                case jsonList of
                  one :: two :: rest ->
                      Result.map3 f
                        (decodeValue a one)
                        (decodeValue b two)
                        (combineResults (List.map (decodeValue c) rest))

                  _ -> Result.Err "expecting at least two elements in the array")

name: Graphics.Collage

aliases.name: LineStyle
aliases.comment:
All of the attributes of a line style. This lets you build up a line style
however you want. You can also update existing line styles with record updates.
aliases.type: { color : Color.Color , width : Float , cap : Graphics.Collage.LineCap , join : Graphics.Collage.LineJoin , dashing : List Int , dashOffset : Int }

types.name: Form
types.comment:
A visual `Form` has a shape and texture. This can be anything from a red
square to a circle textured with stripes.

types.name: LineCap
types.comment: The shape of the ends of a line.

types.name: LineJoin
types.comment:
The shape of the “joints” of a line, where each line segment
meets. `Sharp` takes an argument to limit the length of the joint. This
defaults to 10.

types.name: Path
types.comment: A 2D path. Paths are a sequence of points. They do not have a color.

types.name: Shape
types.comment:
A 2D shape. Shapes are closed polygons. They do not have a color or
texture, that information can be filled in later.

values.name: alpha
values.comment: Set the alpha of a `Form`. The default is 1, and 0 is totally transparent.

values.name: circle
values.comment: A circle with a given radius.

values.name: collage
values.comment:
Create a collage with certain dimensions and content. It takes width and height
arguments to specify dimensions, and then a list of 2D forms to decribe the content.

Unlike with `Element`s, these 2D forms can be moved and rotated however you like.
The forms are drawn in the order of the list, i.e., `collage w h [a, b]` will
draw `b` on top of `a`.

values.name: dashed
values.comment: Create a dashed line style with a given color. Dashing equals `[8,4]`.

values.name: defaultLine
values.comment:
The default line style, which is solid black with flat caps and sharp joints.
You can use record updates to build the line style you
want. For example, to make a thicker line, you could say:

    { defaultLine | width = 10 }

values.name: dotted
values.comment: Create a dotted line style with a given color. Dashing equals `[3,3]`.

values.name: filled
values.comment: Create a filled in shape.

values.name: gradient
values.comment: Fill a shape with a [gradient](Color#linear).

values.name: group
values.comment:
Flatten many forms into a single `Form`. This lets you move and rotate them
as a single unit, making it possible to build small, modular components.
Forms will be drawn in the order that they are listed, as in `collage`.

values.name: groupTransform
values.comment:
Flatten many forms into a single `Form` and then apply a matrix
transformation. Forms will be drawn in the order that they are listed, as in
`collage`.

values.name: move
values.comment:
Move a form by the given amount (x, y). This is a relative translation so
`(move (5,10) form)` would move `form` five pixels to the right and ten pixels up.

values.name: moveX
values.comment:
Move a shape in the x direction. This is relative so `(moveX 10 form)` moves
`form` 10 pixels to the right.

values.name: moveY
values.comment:
Move a shape in the y direction. This is relative so `(moveY 10 form)` moves
`form` upwards by 10 pixels.

values.name: ngon
values.comment:
A regular polygon with N sides. The first argument specifies the number
of sides and the second is the radius. So to create a pentagon with radius
30 you would say:

    ngon 5 30

values.name: outlined
values.comment: Outline a shape with a given line style.

values.name: outlinedText
values.comment:
Create some outlined text. Since we are just outlining the text, the color
is taken from the `LineStyle` attribute instead of the `Text`.

values.name: oval
values.comment: An oval with a given width and height.

values.name: path
values.comment: Create a path that follows a sequence of points.

values.name: polygon
values.comment:
Create an arbitrary polygon by specifying its corners in order.
`polygon` will automatically close all shapes, so the given list
of points does not need to start and end with the same position.

values.name: rect
values.comment: A rectangle with a given width and height.

values.name: rotate
values.comment:
Rotate a form by a given angle. Rotate takes standard Elm angles (radians)
and turns things counterclockwise. So to turn `form` 30° to the left
you would say, `(rotate (degrees 30) form)`.

values.name: scale
values.comment:
Scale a form by a given factor. Scaling by 2 doubles both dimensions,
and quadruples the area.

values.name: segment
values.comment: Create a path along a given line segment.

values.name: solid
values.comment: Create a solid line style with a given color.

values.name: square
values.comment: A square with a given edge length.

values.name: text
values.comment:
Create some text. Details like size and color are part of the `Text` value
itself, so you can mix colors and sizes and fonts easily.

values.name: textured
values.comment:
Create a textured shape. The texture is described by some url and is
tiled to fill the entire shape.

values.name: toForm
values.comment:
Turn any `Element` into a `Form`. This lets you use text, gifs, and video
in your collage. This means you can move, rotate, and scale
an `Element` however you want.

values.name: traced
values.comment: Trace a path with a given line style.

name: Dict

types.name: Dict
types.comment:
A dictionary of keys and values. So a `(Dict String User)` is a dictionary
that lets you look up a `String` (such as user names) and find the associated
`User`.

values.name: diff
values.comment: Keep a key-value pair when its key does not appear in the second dictionary.
values.type: Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v

values.name: empty
values.comment: Create an empty dictionary.

values.name: filter
values.comment: Keep a key-value pair when it satisfies a predicate.
values.type: (comparable -> v -> Bool) -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary, in order from lowest
key to highest key.
values.type: (comparable -> v -> b -> b) -> b -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary, in order from highest
key to lowest key.
values.type: (comparable -> v -> b -> b) -> b -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> b

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Convert an association list into a dictionary.
values.type: List ( comparable, v ) -> Dict.Dict comparable v

values.name: get
values.comment:
Get the value associated with a key. If the key is not found, return
`Nothing`. This is useful when you are not sure if a key will be in the
dictionary.

    animals = fromList [ ("Tom", Cat), ("Jerry", Mouse) ]

    get "Tom"   animals == Just Cat
    get "Jerry" animals == Just Mouse
    get "Spike" animals == Nothing
values.type: comparable -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Maybe.Maybe v

values.name: insert
values.comment:
Insert a key-value pair into a dictionary. Replaces value when there is
a collision.
values.type: comparable -> v -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v

values.name: intersect
values.comment:
Keep a key-value pair when its key appears in the second dictionary.
Preference is given to values in the first dictionary.
values.type: Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment:
Determine if a dictionary is empty.

    isEmpty empty == True

values.name: keys
values.comment:
Get all of the keys in a dictionary, sorted from lowest to highest.

    keys (fromList [(0,"Alice"),(1,"Bob")]) == [0,1]

values.name: map
values.comment: Apply a function to all values in a dictionary.
values.type: (comparable -> a -> b) -> Dict.Dict comparable a -> Dict.Dict comparable b

values.name: member
values.comment: Determine if a key is in a dictionary.

values.name: partition
values.comment:
Partition a dictionary according to a predicate. The first dictionary
contains all key-value pairs which satisfy the predicate, and the second
contains the rest.
values.type: (comparable -> v -> Bool) -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> ( Dict.Dict comparable v, Dict.Dict comparable v )

values.name: remove
values.comment:
Remove a key-value pair from a dictionary. If the key is not found,
no changes are made.
values.type: comparable -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v

values.name: singleton
values.comment: Create a dictionary with one key-value pair.

values.name: size
values.comment: Determine the number of key-value pairs in the dictionary.

values.name: toList
values.comment: Convert a dictionary into an association list of key-value pairs, sorted by keys.
values.type: Dict.Dict comparable v -> List ( comparable, v )

values.name: union
values.comment:
Combine two dictionaries. If there is a collision, preference is given
to the first dictionary.
values.type: Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v

values.name: update
values.comment: Update the value of a dictionary for a specific key with a given function.
values.type: comparable -> (Maybe.Maybe v -> Maybe.Maybe v) -> Dict.Dict comparable v -> Dict.Dict comparable v

values.name: values
values.comment:
Get all of the values in a dictionary, in the order of their keys.

    values (fromList [(0,"Alice"),(1,"Bob")]) == ["Alice", "Bob"]

name: Graphics.Element

types.name: Direction
types.comment: Represents a `flow` direction for a list of elements.

types.name: Element
types.comment:
A graphical element that can be rendered on screen. Every element is a
rectangle with a known width and height, so they can be composed and stacked
easily.

types.name: Pos
types.comment:
Specifies a distance from a particular location within a `container`, like
“20 pixels right and up from the center”. You can use `absolute` or `relative`
to specify a `Pos` in pixels or as a percentage of the container.

types.name: Position
types.comment:
Specifies a position for an element within a `container`, like “the top
left corner”.

values.name: above
values.comment:
Stack elements vertically.
To put `a` above `b` you would say: ``a `above` b``

values.name: absolute
values.comment:
A position specified in pixels. If you want something 10 pixels to the
right of the middle of a container, you would write this:

    middleAt (absolute 10) (absolute 0)

values.name: below
values.comment:
Stack elements vertically.
To put `a` below `b` you would say: ``a `below` b``

values.name: beside
values.comment:
Put elements beside each other horizontally.
To put `a` beside `b` you would say: ``a `beside` b``

values.name: centered
values.comment:
Center text in the text block. There is equal spacing on either side of a
line of text.

values.name: color
values.comment: Create an `Element` with a given background color.

values.name: container
values.comment:
Put an element in a container. This lets you position the element really
easily, and there are tons of ways to set the `Position`.
To center `element` exactly in a 300-by-300 square you would say:

    container 300 300 middle element

By setting the color of the container, you can create borders.

values.name: croppedImage
values.comment:
Create a cropped image. Take a rectangle out of the picture starting
at the given top left coordinate. If you have a 140-by-140 image,
the following will cut a 100-by-100 square out of the middle of it.

    croppedImage (20,20) 100 100 "yogi.jpg"
values.type: ( Int, Int ) -> Int -> Int -> String -> Graphics.Element.Element

values.name: empty
values.comment:
An Element that takes up no space. Good for things that appear conditionally:

    flow down [ img1, if showMore then img2 else empty ]

values.name: fittedImage
values.comment:
Create a fitted image given a width, height, and image source.
This will crop the picture to best fill the given dimensions.

values.name: flow
values.comment:
Have a list of elements flow in a particular direction.
The `Direction` starts from the first element in the list.

    flow right [a,b,c]

        +---+---+---+
        | a | b | c |
        +---+---+---+

values.name: height
values.comment: Create an `Element` with a given height.

values.name: heightOf
values.comment: Get the height of an Element

values.name: image
values.comment: Create an image given a width, height, and image source.

values.name: justified
values.comment:
Align text along the left and right sides of the text block. Word spacing is
adjusted to make this possible.

values.name: layers
values.comment:
Layer elements on top of each other, starting from the bottom:
`layers == flow outward`

values.name: leftAligned
values.comment:
Align text along the left side of the text block. This is sometimes known as
*ragged right*.

values.name: link
values.comment: Create an `Element` that is a hyper-link.

values.name: opacity
values.comment:
Create an `Element` with a given opacity. Opacity is a number between 0 and 1
where 0 means totally clear.

values.name: relative
values.comment:
A position specified as a percentage. If you want something 10% away from
the top left corner, you would say:

    topLeftAt (relative 0.1) (relative 0.1)

values.name: rightAligned
values.comment:
Align text along the right side of the text block. This is sometimes known
as *ragged left*.

values.name: show
values.comment:
Convert anything to its textual representation and make it displayable in
the browser. Excellent for debugging.

    main : Element
    main =
      show "Hello World!"

    show value =
        leftAligned (Text.monospace (Text.fromString (toString value)))

values.name: size
values.comment: Create an `Element` with a new width and height.

values.name: sizeOf
values.comment: Get the width and height of an Element

values.name: spacer
values.comment:
Create an empty box. This is useful for getting your spacing right and
for making borders.

values.name: tag
values.comment:
Create an `Element` with a tag. This lets you link directly to it.
The element `(tag "all-about-badgers" thirdParagraph)` can be reached
with a link like this: `/facts-about-animals.elm#all-about-badgers`

values.name: tiledImage
values.comment:
Create a tiled image. Repeat the image to fill the given width and height.

    tiledImage 100 100 "yogi.jpg"

values.name: width
values.comment: Create an `Element` with a given width.

values.name: widthOf
values.comment: Get the width of an Element

name: Json.Encode

types.name: Value
types.comment: Represents a JavaScript value.

values.name: encode
values.comment:
Convert a `Value` into a prettified string. The first argument specifies
the amount of indentation in the resulting string.

    person =
        object
          [ ("name", string "Tom")
          , ("age", int 42)
          ]

    compact = encode 0 person
    -- {"name":"Tom","age":42}

    readable = encode 4 person
    -- {
    --     "name": "Tom",
    --     "age": 42
    -- }

values.name: float
values.comment: Encode a Float. `Infinity` and `NaN` are encoded as `null`.

name: String

values.name: all
values.comment:
Determine whether *all* characters satisfy a predicate.

    all isDigit "90210" == True
    all isDigit "R2-D2" == False
    all isDigit "heart" == False

values.name: any
values.comment:
Determine whether *any* characters satisfy a predicate.

    any isDigit "90210" == True
    any isDigit "R2-D2" == True
    any isDigit "heart" == False

values.name: append
values.comment:
Append two strings. You can also use [the `(++)` operator](Basics#++)
to do this.

    append "butter" "fly" == "butterfly"

values.name: concat
values.comment:
Concatenate many strings into one.

    concat ["never","the","less"] == "nevertheless"

values.name: cons
values.comment: Add a character to the beginning of a string.

values.name: contains
values.comment:
See if the second string contains the first one.

    contains "the" "theory" == True
    contains "hat" "theory" == False
    contains "THE" "theory" == False

Use [`Regex.contains`](Regex#contains) if you need something more flexible.

values.name: dropLeft
values.comment: Drop *n* characters from the left side of a string.

values.name: dropRight
values.comment: Drop *n* characters from the right side of a string.

values.name: endsWith
values.comment:
See if the second string ends with the first one.

    endsWith "the" "theory" == False
    endsWith "ory" "theory" == True

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Keep only the characters that satisfy the predicate.

    filter isDigit "R2-D2" == "22"

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Reduce a string from the left.

    foldl cons "" "time" == "emit"

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Reduce a string from the right.

    foldr cons "" "time" == "time"

values.name: fromChar
values.comment:
Create a string from a given character.

    fromChar 'a' == "a"

values.name: fromList
values.comment:
Convert a list of characters into a String. Can be useful if you
want to create a string primarily by consing, perhaps for decoding
something.

    fromList ['a','b','c'] == "abc"

values.name: indexes
values.comment:
Get all of the indexes for a substring in another string.

    indexes "i" "Mississippi"   == [1,4,7,10]
    indexes "ss" "Mississippi"  == [2,5]
    indexes "needle" "haystack" == []

values.name: indices
values.comment: Alias for `indexes`.

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment:
Determine if a string is empty.

    isEmpty "" == True
    isEmpty "the world" == False

values.name: join
values.comment:
Put many strings together with a given separator.

    join "a" ["H","w","ii","n"]        == "Hawaiian"
    join " " ["cat","dog","cow"]       == "cat dog cow"
    join "/" ["home","evan","Desktop"] == "home/evan/Desktop"

values.name: left
values.comment: Take *n* characters from the left side of a string.

values.name: length
values.comment:
Get the length of a string.

    length "innumerable" == 11
    length "" == 0

values.name: lines
values.comment:
Break a string into lines, splitting on newlines.

    lines "How are you?\nGood?" == ["How are you?", "Good?"]

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform every character in a string

    map (\c -> if c == '/' then '.' else c) "a/b/c" == "a.b.c"

values.name: pad
values.comment:
Pad a string on both sides until it has a given length.

    pad 5 ' ' "1"   == "  1  "
    pad 5 ' ' "11"  == "  11 "
    pad 5 ' ' "121" == " 121 "

values.name: padLeft
values.comment:
Pad a string on the left until it has a given length.

    padLeft 5 '.' "1"   == "....1"
    padLeft 5 '.' "11"  == "...11"
    padLeft 5 '.' "121" == "..121"

values.name: padRight
values.comment:
Pad a string on the right until it has a given length.

    padRight 5 '.' "1"   == "1...."
    padRight 5 '.' "11"  == "11..."
    padRight 5 '.' "121" == "121.."

values.name: repeat
values.comment:
Repeat a string *n* times.

    repeat 3 "ha" == "hahaha"

values.name: reverse
values.comment:
Reverse a string.

    reverse "stressed" == "desserts"

values.name: right
values.comment: Take *n* characters from the right side of a string.

values.name: slice
values.comment:
Take a substring given a start and end index. Negative indexes
are taken starting from the *end* of the list.

    slice  7  9 "snakes on a plane!" == "on"
    slice  0  6 "snakes on a plane!" == "snakes"
    slice  0 -7 "snakes on a plane!" == "snakes on a"
    slice -6 -1 "snakes on a plane!" == "plane"

values.name: split
values.comment:
Split a string using a given separator.

    split "," "cat,dog,cow"        == ["cat","dog","cow"]
    split "/" "home/evan/Desktop/" == ["home","evan","Desktop", ""]

Use [`Regex.split`](Regex#split) if you need something more flexible.

values.name: startsWith
values.comment:
See if the second string starts with the first one.

    startsWith "the" "theory" == True
    startsWith "ory" "theory" == False

values.name: toFloat
values.comment:
Try to convert a string into a float, failing on improperly formatted strings.

    toFloat "123" == Ok 123.0
    toFloat "-42" == Ok -42.0
    toFloat "3.1" == Ok 3.1
    toFloat "31a" == Err "could not convert string '31a' to a Float"

values.name: toInt
values.comment:
Try to convert a string into an int, failing on improperly formatted strings.

    toInt "123" == Ok 123
    toInt "-42" == Ok -42
    toInt "3.1" == Err "could not convert string '3.1' to an Int"
    toInt "31a" == Err "could not convert string '31a' to an Int"

values.name: toList
values.comment:
Convert a string to a list of characters.

    toList "abc" == ['a','b','c']

values.name: toLower
values.comment: Convert a string to all lower case. Useful for case-insensitive comparisons.

values.name: toUpper
values.comment:
Convert a string to all upper case. Useful for case-insensitive comparisons
and VIRTUAL YELLING.

values.name: trim
values.comment:
Get rid of whitespace on both sides of a string.

    trim "  hats  \n" == "hats"

values.name: trimLeft
values.comment:
Get rid of whitespace on the left of a string.

    trimLeft "  hats  \n" == "hats  \n"

values.name: trimRight
values.comment:
Get rid of whitespace on the right of a string.

    trimRight "  hats  \n" == "  hats"

values.name: uncons
values.comment:
Split a non-empty string into its head and tail. This lets you
pattern match on strings exactly as you would with lists.

    uncons "abc" == Just ('a',"bc")
    uncons ""    == Nothing

values.name: words
values.comment:
Break a string into words, splitting on chunks of whitespace.

    words "How are \t you? \n Good?" == ["How","are","you?","Good?"]

name: Text
comment:
A library for styling and displaying text. While the
[`String`](String) library focuses on representing and manipulating
strings of character strings, the `Text` library focuses on how those
strings should look on screen. It lets you make text bold or italic,
set the typeface, set the text size, etc.

# Text
@docs Text

# Creating Text
@docs fromString, empty, append, concat, join

# Links and Style
@docs link, typeface, monospace, height, color, bold, italic, line, Line,
    style, Style, defaultStyle

aliases.name: Style
aliases.comment:
Represents all the ways you can style `Text`. If the `typeface` list is
empty or the `height` is `Nothing`, the users will fall back on their browser's
default settings. The following `Style` is black, 16 pixel tall, underlined, and
Times New Roman (assuming that typeface is available on the user's computer):

    { typeface = [ "Times New Roman", "serif" ]
    , height   = Just 16
    , color    = black
    , bold     = False
    , italic   = False
    , line     = Just Under
    }
aliases.type: { typeface : List String , height : Maybe.Maybe Float , color : Color.Color , bold : Bool , italic : Bool , line : Maybe.Maybe Text.Line }

types.name: Line
types.comment:
Styles for lines on text. This allows you to add an underline, an overline,
or a strike out text:

    line Under   (fromString "underline")
    line Over    (fromString "overline")
    line Through (fromString "strike out")

types.name: Text
types.comment: Represents styled text. It can be rendered with collages or with elements.

values.name: append
values.comment:
Put two chunks of text together.

    append (fromString "hello ") (fromString "world") == fromString "hello world"

values.name: bold
values.comment:
Make text bold.

    fromString "sometimes you want " ++ bold (fromString "emphasis")

values.name: color
values.comment:
Set the color of some text.

    color red (fromString "Red")

values.name: concat
values.comment:
Put many chunks of text together.

    concat
      [ fromString "type "
      , bold (fromString "Maybe")
      , fromString " = Just a | Nothing"
      ]

values.name: defaultStyle
values.comment:
Plain black text. It uses the browsers default typeface and text height.
No decorations are used.

    { typeface = []
    , height = Nothing
    , color = black
    , bold = False
    , italic = False
    , line = Nothing
    }

values.name: empty
values.comment:
Text with nothing in it.

    empty = fromString ""

values.name: fromString
values.comment:
Convert a string into text which can be styled and displayed. To show the
string `"Hello World!"` on screen in italics, you could say:

    main = leftAligned (italic (fromString "Hello World!"))

values.name: height
values.comment:
Set the height of some text.

    height 40 (fromString "Title")

values.name: italic
values.comment:
Make text italic.

    fromString "make it " ++ italic (fromString "important")

values.name: join
values.comment:
Put many chunks of text together with a separator.

    chunks : List Text
    chunks = List.map fromString ["lions","tigers","bears"]

    join (fromString ", ") chunks == fromString "lions, tigers, bears"

values.name: line
values.comment:
Put lines on text.

    line Under   (fromString "underlined")
    line Over    (fromString "overlined")
    line Through (fromString "strike out")

values.name: link
values.comment:
Create a link by providing a URL and the text of the link.

    link "http://elm-lang.org" (fromString "Elm Website")

values.name: monospace
values.comment:
Switch to a monospace typeface. Good for code snippets.

    monospace (fromString "foldl (+) 0 [1,2,3]")

values.name: style
values.comment:
Set the style of some text. For example, if you design a `Style` called
`footerStyle` that is specifically for the bottom of your page, you could apply
it to text like this:

    style footerStyle (fromString "the old prince / 2007")

values.name: typeface
values.comment:
Provide a list of preferred typefaces for some text.

    ["helvetica","arial","sans-serif"]

Not every browser has access to the same typefaces, so rendering will use the
first typeface in the list that is found on the user's computer. If there are
no matches, it will use their default typeface. This works the same as the CSS
font-family property.

name: Array

types.name: Array
types.comment:
Representation of fast immutable arrays. You can create arrays of integers
(`Array Int`) or strings (`Array String`) or any other type of value you can
dream up.

values.name: append
values.comment:
Append two arrays to a new one.

    append (repeat 2 42) (repeat 3 81) == fromList [42,42,81,81,81]
values.type: Array.Array a -> Array.Array a -> Array.Array a

values.name: empty
values.comment:
Return an empty array.

    length empty == 0

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Keep only elements that satisfy the predicate:

    filter isEven (fromList [1..6]) == (fromList [2,4,6])

values.name: foldl
values.comment:
Reduce an array from the left. Read `foldl` as “fold from the left”.

    foldl (::) [] (fromList [1,2,3]) == [3,2,1]
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Array.Array a -> b

values.name: foldr
values.comment:
Reduce an array from the right. Read `foldr` as “fold from the right”.

    foldr (+) 0 (repeat 3 5) == 15
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Array.Array a -> b

values.name: fromList
values.comment: Create an array from a list.

values.name: get
values.comment:
Return Just the element at the index or Nothing if the index is out of range.

    get  0 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Just 0
    get  2 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Just 2
    get  5 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Nothing
    get -1 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Nothing

values.name: indexedMap
values.comment:
Apply a function on every element with its index as first argument.

    indexedMap (*) (fromList [5,5,5]) == fromList [0,5,10]
values.type: (Int -> a -> b) -> Array.Array a -> Array.Array b

values.name: initialize
values.comment:
Initialize an array. `initialize n f` creates an array of length `n` with
the element at index `i` initialized to the result of `(f i)`.

    initialize 4 identity    == fromList [0,1,2,3]
    initialize 4 (\n -> n*n) == fromList [0,1,4,9]
    initialize 4 (always 0)  == fromList [0,0,0,0]

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment:
Determine if an array is empty.

    isEmpty empty == True

values.name: length
values.comment:
Return the length of an array.

    length (fromList [1,2,3]) == 3

values.name: map
values.comment:
Apply a function on every element in an array.

    map sqrt (fromList [1,4,9]) == fromList [1,2,3]

values.name: push
values.comment:
Push an element to the end of an array.

    push 3 (fromList [1,2]) == fromList [1,2,3]

values.name: repeat
values.comment:
Creates an array with a given length, filled with a default element.

    repeat 5 0     == fromList [0,0,0,0,0]
    repeat 3 "cat" == fromList ["cat","cat","cat"]

Notice that `repeat 3 x` is the same as `initialize 3 (always x)`.

values.name: set
values.comment:
Set the element at a particular index. Returns an updated array.
If the index is out of range, the array is unaltered.

    set 1 7 (fromList [1,2,3]) == fromList [1,7,3]
values.type: Int -> a -> Array.Array a -> Array.Array a

values.name: slice
values.comment:
Get a sub-section of an array: `(slice start end array)`. The `start` is a
zero-based index where we will start our slice. The `end` is a zero-based index
that indicates the end of the slice. The slice extracts up to but not including
`end`.

    slice  0  3 (fromList [0,1,2,3,4]) == fromList [0,1,2]
    slice  1  4 (fromList [0,1,2,3,4]) == fromList [1,2,3]

Both the `start` and `end` indexes can be negative, indicating an offset from
the end of the array.

    slice  1 -1 (fromList [0,1,2,3,4]) == fromList [1,2,3]
    slice -2  5 (fromList [0,1,2,3,4]) == fromList [3,4]

This makes it pretty easy to `pop` the last element off of an array: `slice 0 -1 array`
values.type: Int -> Int -> Array.Array a -> Array.Array a

values.name: toIndexedList
values.comment:
Create an indexed list from an array. Each element of the array will be
paired with its index.

    toIndexedList (fromList ["cat","dog"]) == [(0,"cat"), (1,"dog")]

values.name: toList
values.comment:
Create a list of elements from an array.

    toList (fromList [3,5,8]) == [3,5,8]

name: Random
comment:
This library helps you generate pseudo-random values.

This library is all about building [`generators`](#Generator) for whatever
type of values you need. There are a bunch of primitive generators like
[`bool`](#bool) and [`int`](#int) that you can build up into fancier
generators with functions like [`list`](#list) and [`map`](#map).

You use a `Generator` by running the [`generate`](#generate) function. If you
need random values across many frames, you will probably want to store the
most recent seed in your application state.

*Note:* This is an implementation of the Portable Combined Generator of
L'Ecuyer for 32-bit computers. It is almost a direct translation from the
[System.Random](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/random-1.0.1.1/docs/System-Random.html)
module. It has a period of roughly 2.30584e18.

# Generators
@docs Generator

# Primitive Generators
@docs bool, int, float

# Data Structure Generators
@docs pair, list

# Custom Generators
@docs map, map2, map3, map4, map5, andThen

# Run a Generator
@docs generate, Seed, initialSeed

# Constants
@docs maxInt, minInt

types.name: Generator
types.comment:
A `Generator` is like a recipe for generating certain random values. So a
`Generator Int` describes how to generate integers and a `Generator String`
describes how to generate strings.

To actually *run* a generator and produce the random values, you need to use
functions like [`generate`](#generate) and [`initialSeed`](#initialSeed).

types.name: Seed
types.comment:
A `Seed` is the source of randomness in this whole system. Whenever
you want to use a generator, you need to pair it with a seed.

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
Chain random operations, threading through the seed. In the following
example, we will generate a random letter by putting together uppercase and
lowercase letters.

    letter : Generator Char
    letter =
      bool `andThen` \b ->
        if b then uppercaseLetter else lowercaseLetter

    -- bool : Generator Bool
    -- uppercaseLetter : Generator Char
    -- lowercaseLetter : Generator Char
values.type: Random.Generator a -> (a -> Random.Generator b) -> Random.Generator b

values.name: bool
values.comment:
Create a generator that produces boolean values. The following example
simulates a coin flip that may land heads or tails.

    type Flip = Heads | Tails

    coinFlip : Generator Flip
    coinFlip =
        map (\b -> if b then Heads else Tails) bool

values.name: float
values.comment:
Generate floats in a given range. The following example is a generator
that produces decimals between 0 and 1.

    probability : Generator Float
    probability =
        float 0 1

values.name: generate
values.comment:
Generate a random value as specified by a given `Generator`.

In the following example, we are trying to generate a number between 0 and 100
with the `int 0 100` generator. Each time we call `generate` we need to provide
a seed. This will produce a random number and a *new* seed to use if we want to
run other generators later.

So here it is done right, where we get a new seed from each `generate` call and
thread that through.

    seed0 = initialSeed 31415

    -- generate (int 0 100) seed0 ==> (42, seed1)
    -- generate (int 0 100) seed1 ==> (31, seed2)
    -- generate (int 0 100) seed2 ==> (99, seed3)

Notice that we use different seeds on each line. This is important! If you use
the same seed, you get the same results.

    -- generate (int 0 100) seed0 ==> (42, seed1)
    -- generate (int 0 100) seed0 ==> (42, seed1)
    -- generate (int 0 100) seed0 ==> (42, seed1)

values.name: initialSeed
values.comment:
Create a “seed” of randomness which makes it possible to
generate random values. If you use the same seed many times, it will result
in the same thing every time! A good way to get an unexpected seed is to use
the current time.

values.name: int
values.comment:
Generate 32-bit integers in a given range.

    int 0 10   -- an integer between zero and ten
    int -5 5   -- an integer between -5 and 5

    int minInt maxInt  -- an integer in the widest range feasible

This function *can* produce values outside of the range [[`minInt`](#minInt),
[`maxInt`](#maxInt)] but sufficient randomness is not guaranteed.

values.name: list
values.comment:
Create a list of random values.

    floatList : Generator (List Float)
    floatList =
        list 10 (float 0 1)

    intList : Generator (List Int)
    intList =
        list 5 (int 0 100)

    intPairs : Generator (List (Int, Int))
    intPairs =
        list 10 <| pair (int 0 100) (int 0 100)

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the values produced by a generator. The following examples show
how to generate booleans and letters based on a basic integer generator.

    bool : Generator Bool
    bool =
      map ((==) 1) (int 0 1)

    lowercaseLetter : Generator Char
    lowercaseLetter =
      map (\n -> Char.fromCode (n + 97)) (int 0 25)

    uppercaseLetter : Generator Char
    uppercaseLetter =
      map (\n -> Char.fromCode (n + 65)) (int 0 25)

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Combine two generators.

This function is used to define things like [`pair`](#pair) where you want to
put two generators together.

    pair : Generator a -> Generator b -> Generator (a,b)
    pair genA genB =
      map2 (,) genA genB
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> Random.Generator a -> Random.Generator b -> Random.Generator c

values.name: map3
values.comment:
Combine three generators. This could be used to produce random colors.

    import Color

    rgb : Generator Color.Color
    rgb =
      map3 Color.rgb (int 0 255) (int 0 255) (int 0 255)

    hsl : Generator Color.Color
    hsl =
      map3 Color.hsl (map degrees (int 0 360)) (float 0 1) (float 0 1)
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d) -> Random.Generator a -> Random.Generator b -> Random.Generator c -> Random.Generator d

values.name: map4
values.comment: Combine four generators.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e) -> Random.Generator a -> Random.Generator b -> Random.Generator c -> Random.Generator d -> Random.Generator e

values.name: map5
values.comment: Combine five generators.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f) -> Random.Generator a -> Random.Generator b -> Random.Generator c -> Random.Generator d -> Random.Generator e -> Random.Generator f

values.name: maxInt
values.comment: The maximum value for randomly generated 32-bit ints.

values.name: minInt
values.comment: The minimum value for randomly generated 32-bit ints.

values.name: pair
values.comment:
Create a pair of random values. A common use of this might be to generate
a point in a certain 2D space. Imagine we have a collage that is 400 pixels
wide and 200 pixels tall.

    randomPoint : Generator (Int,Int)
    randomPoint =
        pair (int -200 200) (int -100 100)
values.type: Random.Generator a -> Random.Generator b -> Random.Generator ( a, b )

name: Task

types.name: Task
types.comment:
Represents asynchronous effects that may fail. It is useful for stuff like
HTTP.

For example, maybe we have a task with the type (`Task String User`). This means
that when we perform the task, it will either fail with a `String` message or
succeed with a `User`. So this could represent a task that is asking a server
for a certain user.

types.name: ThreadID
types.comment: Abstract type that uniquely identifies a thread.

values.name: andMap
values.comment:
Put the results of two tasks together. If either task fails, the whole
thing fails. It also runs in order so the first task will be completely
finished before the second task starts.

This function makes it possible to chain tons of tasks together and pipe them
all into a single function.

    (f `map` task1 `andMap` task2 `andMap` task3) == map3 f task1 task2 task3
